timeline.subject: Jacotte Raon
timeline.details: Carried out by Nicolas Pirouel, prévôt d'Arches, at request of substitut for PG

timeline.subject: Jacotte Raon
timeline.details: Procureur General des Vosges orders arrest and examination

timeline.subject: Jacotte Raon
timeline.details: First interrogation - denied accusations, said they were made out of envy

timeline.subject: Jacotte Raon
timeline.details: Confronted with witnesses - made vehement denials

timeline.subject: Jacotte Raon
timeline.details: PG des Vosges asks for question extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Jacotte Raon
timeline.details: Racked and given water; persisted in denying guilt

timeline.subject: Jacotte Raon
timeline.details: PG des Vosges requests life imprisonment if her goods insufficient, husband must provide. Notes resistance to torture probably mere obstinacy

timeline.subject: Jacotte Raon
timeline.details: Change de Nancy postpones decision until new evidence evaluated. Letter from dame secrette appended

timeline.subject: Jacotte Raon
timeline.details: Continued denials; invoked Jesus and St Nicolas. More confrontations followed

timeline.subject: Jacotte Raon
timeline.details: Procureur General des Vosges asks that she be tortured again

timeline.subject: Jacotte Raon
timeline.details: Change de Nancy orders interrogation in presence of torture instruments but not actually tortured. If she won't confess, banish from duchy

timeline.subject: Jacotte Raon
timeline.details: Prévôt d'Arches has her taken to torture chamber; when she refuses to confess orders banishment

torture.restrictions: Second torture request denied - only shown instruments without application

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacotte Raon to Nicolas Estiennon Boudart
notable_quotes.french: qu'il luy empescheroit ses arbres, et boucheroit son jour, et qu'il s'en repentiroit
notable_quotes.english: that he would block her trees and her light, and he would repent of it
notable_quotes.context: Threat after witness bought land next to her house

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacotte Raon
notable_quotes.context: Speaking to Nicolas Estiennon Boudart while he was sowing, before his 5-week illness

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacotte Raon to Bertrand Jacot
notable_quotes.french: qu'il s'en repentiroit, que la cloison luy seroit bien chere
notable_quotes.english: that he would repent, that the fence would cost him dearly

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge (Jacotte's late son) to Bertrand Jacot
notable_quotes.french: Hola, hola, votre poulain n'est pas encore perdu
notable_quotes.english: Hold on, hold on, your foal is not yet lost
notable_quotes.context: After Jacot threatened to have Jacotte burned if she didn't cure his foal

notable_quotes.speaker: Julienne's stepfather (witness 9) about Jacotte
notable_quotes.french: que devant qu'il soit un an il n'y en moudroit plus
notable_quotes.english: that before a year he would not mill there anymore
notable_quotes.context: Jacotte's threat after stepfather removed her corn from mill; he and family died within two weeks

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudotte (witness 10)
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle ne l'auroit pas, ou que le diable y cheorroit
notable_quotes.english: that she would not have it, or the devil would fall there
notable_quotes.context: Jacotte's words during land sale dispute

notable_quotes.speaker: Thienon Blaise's father to Jacotte
notable_quotes.french: qu'il estoit engenauché comme les autres
notable_quotes.english: that he was bewitched like the others

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacotte Raon
notable_quotes.context: Her reply to father's bewitchment comment

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacotte Raon (in interrogation)
notable_quotes.french: par envye d'autant que son marit et elle font bon mesnage (dieu mercy) et qu'ilz marient en bons lieux leurs enffans
notable_quotes.english: out of envy because her husband and she keep a good household (thank God) and they marry their children into good families
notable_quotes.context: Her explanation for why accusations were made

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacotte Raon (in interrogation)
notable_quotes.french: femme de bien et bonne mesnagere, aiant si bien travaillé avec son marit que moyennant la grace de dieu ils ont amassés plusieurs beaux biens; et pense fermement que cela est la principale cause de ce qu'elle peult estre haye ou mal voulue de quelques habitants de Xennenay
notable_quotes.english: a good woman and good housewife, having worked so well with her husband that by the grace of God they have accumulated many fine goods; and firmly believes this is the principal reason she may be hated or ill-regarded by some inhabitants of Xennenay
notable_quotes.context: Her defense - blaming envy of economic success

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas le Clerc (witness 21) reporting Jacotte's words
notable_quotes.context: What Jacotte said she was when being escorted to prison, though she had feared it for 20 years

notable_quotes.speaker: Marguerite femme de Nicolas le Clerc (witness 22) reporting Jacotte
notable_quotes.french: que possible seroit elle encor perdue
notable_quotes.english: that possibly she would be lost/destroyed
notable_quotes.context: Jacotte's fear if she went to prison in old chemise

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacotte Raon (in interrogation)
notable_quotes.french: comment est ce que Jesus ne fait pas ses miracles
notable_quotes.english: how is it that Jesus does not perform his miracles

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudotte widow of Demengeon de Ranfaing
notable_quotes.french: puis se retira en sa maison, en menacant et grondant entre ses dents
notable_quotes.english: then withdrew to her house, threatening and grumbling between her teeth
notable_quotes.context: After reproaching tax collector husband about rates

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over land purchases and boundaries. Jacotte and her husband were economically successful - she stated they had 'accumulated many fine goods' through hard work, married children into good families. She attributed accusations to envy of their prosperity. Disputes included: Nicolas Estiennon Boudart buying land next to her house (she offered twice the price to prevent it); boundary disputes over hedges and 'cloisons'; land sales to neighbors she disapproved of; tithe collection disputes.

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Held at Arches prison, jailer testified she was 'forte robuste' and declared herself ready to die rather than confess. No special treatment from relatives. Complained about wearing old chemise when arrested.

knew about Jacotte and daughter visiting and making soup from wife, as he had not been really conscious
often heard neighbors complain of 'desplaisir' she had done them
heard that Jacotte's daughters were angry about not being asked to dance
neighbors advised her to go to Xennenay and complain to Jacotte

emotional_state_notes: Made vehement denials of accusations during confrontations
Declared herself ready to die rather than confess

extraction_metadata.notes: Exceptionally detailed trial with 31 witnesses. Jacotte was accused of numerous maleficia over 25-30 years, primarily against neighbors in property and boundary disputes. She maintained innocence throughout, attributing accusations to envy of her family's economic success. She withstood torture and was ultimately banished rather than executed. Notable features: (1) Pattern of threats followed by harms within days/weeks; (2) Many cures allegedly performed by Jacotte visiting sick people and giving them soup/food; (3) Strong economic success theme - she emphasized good household management and children marrying well; (4) 'dame secrette de Remyremont' wrote influential letter urging continued imprisonment; (5) Very high number of animal deaths attributed to her, especially livestock losses after property disputes; (6) Multiple family deaths in witness 9's testimony (stepfather, mother, two brothers within two weeks of mill dispute). Trial lasted nearly 6 months with extensive witness testimony and legal proceedings.
